Name: Pattern Recognition - PE

Name: Deductive Reasoning - IND
Text: So the chain is Preliminary_Credit_Check Gather_Additional_Documents Quality_Assurance_Review Assemble_Loan_Offer_Package Transfer_Funds Notify_Customer And Authorize_Contract_Terms must happen immediately after Preliminary_Credit_Check But Succession says Preliminary_Credit_Check must eventually be followed by Gather_Additional_Documents

Name: Validation - NE
Text: This is a conflict Chainprecedence Authorize must be immediately preceded by Preliminary Precedence Authorize can only happen if QA happened before So QA must happen before Authorize and Preliminary must happen immediately before Authorize This implies QA happens before Preliminary But Altsuccession says Gather QA and Succession says Preliminary Gather So Preliminary Gather QA This is a contradiction in the model

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Wait let me double-check DECLARE semantics Chain precedence B can only occur if A occurred immediately before B Let me reconsider the DECLARE semantics carefully Standard DECLARE constraints from van der Aalst Precedence A B B requires A before Chain Precedence A B B requires A immediately before Looking at the Python dictionary format key is antecedent A target is consequent B for most but trying different interpretations of dictionary direction

Text: The model contains a deliberate inconsistency or there is a specific interpretation where these constraints can coexist Perhaps Authorize_Contract_Terms happens immediately after Preliminary_Credit_Check in parallel with document gathering while QA provides verification Or chainprecedence refers to logical dependency not strict temporal immediacy
